Thanks David, the part in the command line application was exactly what I w=
as looking for. The results become better and better. In a few days I won't=
 need a tutorial anymore :).

Cheers,
Daniel


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "ddambroeplex" <ddambro84@...> wrote:
>
> Part of the problem you are expe=
riencing is that SharpNEAT and HyperSharpNEAT (and apparently Matt Buckland=
's code, based on a recent post) don't reevaluate genomes that have already=
 been evaluated.  This method works great with deterministic, static fitnes=
s functions, but if you change the fitness during evolution as you are doin=
g, you will have to change the code slightly.
> 
> If you're using the Sing=
leFilePopulationEvaluator, simply comment out lines 44 and 45 (if(g.Evaluat=
ionCount!=3D0) continue;).  If you're using the multi-threaded one the rele=
vant code should already be commented out, but you can check on line 113 of=
 MultiThreadedPopulationEvaluator.  
> 
> The best fitness in the Evolution=
Algorithm class is calculated based on the fitnesses of the current populat=
ion, so as long as you are reevaluating everything you shouldn't have to wo=
rry about resetting that.  However If you are using my CommandLineEvolution=
 code, you will have to reset the maxFitness variable, otherwise it won't o=
utput new genome XML until you beat the old maxFitness value.
> 
> --- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel" <daniel_kuppitz@> wrote:
> >
> > Right now I =
train my network on a single set of input data. After reaching a predefined=
 fitness value I switch over to the next set of input data. When the fitnes=
s is too low the training begins for this data and continues until the pred=
efined fitness value is reached and so on.
> > After a few iterations the n=
etwork produces perfect outputs on some sets of data. Consequently the best=
 fitness value is extremly high. When I now switch to a new set of data it'=
s nearly impossible to reach this fitness and so the best genome will never=
 change again, even if it performs really bad on different inputs.
> > My i=
dea was that I could reset the best fitness each time when I change the inp=
ut data. The data is changed within the EvaluateNetwork method; is there al=
so a way to reset the best fitness from within this method? Or should I bet=
ter change the whole workflow?
